Venue for the 2009 Junior Eurovision.]] The [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU) invited broadcasters to bid for the rights to host the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2009; three bids were received from Belarus, Serbia, and Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=3557|title=Three bids for Junior Eurovision 2009|last=Konstantopoulos|first=Fotis|date=2008-06-02|publisher=''Oikotimes''|accessdate=2008-12-04}} [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]] of Sweden had originally sent in a bid during summer 2007, but soon withdrew its bid after deciding to completely withdraw from the contest.{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=883|title=TV4 is the third bidding broadcaster for JESC 2009|date=2007-09-14|publisher=''Oikotimes''|accessdate=2008-12-04}} After deliberations by the EBU, [[National Television Company of Ukraine]] was granted the rights to the 2009 contest and would host it in [[Kiev]].{{cite web|publisher=''ESCToday''|date=2008-06-06 |url= http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12069|title= JESC - Ukraine: To host Junior Eurovision 2009|accessdate=2008-06-18|author=Floras, Stella}} Ukraine also hosted the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005]] at the same venue. On 12 November 2009 Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister [[Ivan Vasiunyk]] declared that the contest would not be postponed; (earlier) [[Party of Regions]] [[Verkhovna Rada#Composition|member of parliament]] [[Hanna Herman]] had called on [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] to cancel the song contest because of the [[2009 flu pandemic in Europe#Ukraine|2009 flu pandemic in Ukraine]].[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/24766/ Ukraine will not postpone Junior Eurovision 2009 over flu outbreak - official], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (13 November 2009) Both Prime Minister Tymoshenko and [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yushchenko]] were present during the final; Tymoshenko was also present and speeched during the opening ceremony on 16 November 2009.[http://photo.unian.net/eng/themes/15425?fp=40 Events by themes: Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2009], [[UNIAN]] (November 21, 2009) ==Concept and logo== Logo of the contest titled "[[Tree of life]]" is based on the artwork "Sunflower of life" by [[Maria Primachenko]], a well known Ukrainian folk art painter. Creative design of the show was based on the logo of the contest, works and ideas of Primachenko as well as on the concept of the show, titled "For the joy of people".{{cite web|url=http://esckaz.com/jesc/2009/event.htm|title=Logo and concept of Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2009 have been presented|date=2009-08-11|accessdate=2009-08-11|publisher=''ESCKaz''}} ==Participants== The EBU announced the complete list of participating countries in the 2009 Contest on 8 June 2009. 13 countries competed in the contest: Armenia, Belarus, Belgium, Cyprus, Georgia, Macedonia, Malta, Netherlands, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Sweden and Ukraine. [[Sweden]] returned after missing the contest, while [[Bulgaria in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest|Bulgaria]], [[Greece in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest|Greece]] and [[Lithuania in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest|Lithuania]] withdrew from the Contest. ==Final== Each country decided their votes through a 50% jury and 50% televoting system which decided their top ten songs using the points 12, 10, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, and 1. {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} [[File:Karneval der Kulturen in Berlin.jpg|thumb|Karneval der Kulturen in Berlin]] [[File:Karneval der Kulturen 2009 18.jpg|thumb|2009]] [[File:Kar Kult 2006 1.jpg|thumb|2006]] '''Karneval der Kulturen''' (Carnival of Cultures) is a multicultural festival in [[Kreuzberg]], [[Berlin]], celebrated annually around [[Pentecost]] weekend since 1996. It is organised by the Werkstatt der Kulturen. The processions, theatre performances, and music events celebrate peace, tolerance, and multiculturalism.
== History == The Werkstatt der Kulturen was founded in October 1993 in [[Neukölln]], Berlin, patronised by the [[Berlin Senate]]. The first Karneval der Kulturen took place on 15 and 16 May 1996 around [[Feast of the Ascension|Ascension Thursday]]. It was inspired by other European carnevals such as the [[Notting Hill Carnival]] in [[London]] and the [[Summer Carnival|Zomercarnaval]] in [[Rotterdam]].
The Karneval der Kulturen then grew to a four-day festival with numerous musical and theatrical performances. The number of visitors grew from 50,000 in 1996 to 300,000 in 1997, 1 million in 2000<ref>{{cite book|title=Wer sich maskiert, wird integriert. Der Karneval der Kulturen in Berlin|last=Frei|first=Kerstin|date=2003|publisher=Schiler|isbn=3-89930-008-4|location=Berlin}}</ref>, to more than one million in 2018.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tagesspiegel.de/berlin/karneval-der-kulturen-ueber-1-millionen-menschen-feiern-friedlich-in-berlin/22587322.html|title=Über 1 Millionen Menschen feiern friedlich in Berlin|access-date=2018-10-29|language=de}}</ref> The number of participants also grew from 2,200 to more than 4,000,<ref>http://de.indymedia.org//2004/05/84423.shtml</ref> organised into 66 procession group (2018).<ref name=":0" /> These procession groups come from all over Germany, but also include South American and African groups.<ref>{{cite book |last=Knecht |first=Michi |date=2007 |title=Wie der Karneval der Kulturen denkt, lernt und Kultur macht |location=Berlin |publisher=Panama-Verlag |isbn=978-3-938714-01-0}}</ref>

{{Infobox recurring event | |name=Kentucky Derby Festival |logo= |image= Louisville fireworks.jpg |imagesize= 250px |caption= Thunder Over Louisville |location=[[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]], [[United States]] |years_active=1935–1937, 1956–present |dates=The two weeks prior to the [[Kentucky Derby]] |genre= Horse racing |website=http://kdf.org/ }} The '''Kentucky Derby Festival''' is an annual festival held in [[Louisville, Kentucky]] during the two weeks preceding the first Saturday in May, the day of the [[Kentucky Derby]]. The festival, [[Kentucky]]'s largest single annual event, first ran from 1935 to 1937, and restarted in 1956<ref>The Derby itself began in 1875 at [[Churchill Downs]].</ref> and includes: * '''[[Thunder Over Louisville]]''', the largest annual [[fireworks|fireworks display]] in North America; * the '''Great [[Hot air ballooning#Competition|Balloon Race]]'''; * '''[[Great Steamboat Race|The Great Steamboat Race]]''', featuring the ''[[Belle of Louisville]]''; * the '''Pegasus Parade''', one of the largest [[parade]]s in the [[United States]]; and * the '''Kentucky Derby Festival [[Marathon]]''' & '''[[Mini marathon|miniMarathon]]'''. * the Kentucky Derby Festival Basketball Classic
==History== The Kentucky Derby Festival Association started the first week-long festival in 1935, including a parade, a riverfront regatta and an orchestral concert. The first director was Olympic gold medalist [[Arnold Jackson (athlete)|Arnold Jackson]]. In 1937, a Derby Festival king and queen were crowned, marking the start of this tradition. After the floods of 1937, the festival was discontinued and it was not until 1956 when the modern-day Kentucky Derby Festival was reborn.
==Official events== {{Refimprove section|date=April 2008}} Events vary from year to year but always include numerous athletic events, including the miniMarathon and Marathon; concerts; fashion shows; wine tastings; luncheons and private parties ranging from backyard barbecues to lavish Derby Eve balls attended by entertainment stars, famed athletes and other persons of note.
===The Royal Court=== The Royal Court is among the oldest traditions of the Kentucky Derby Festival tradition, dating back to the 1950s by The Fillies, Inc. The Royal Court consists of a group of five young women chosen to preside over events related to the Kentucky Derby. These women officially represent both the Derby Festival and the city of Louisville.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.derbycraze.com/kentucky-derby-festivals.html |title=Famous Kentucky Derby Festivals |website=derbycraze.com |accessdate=5 August 2013}}</ref> In January, a court of Derby Princesses is selected from a pool of more than 1000 applicants. Thirty finalists are selected and the pool is then reduced to five young women who make up the court. Criteria for the selection of the court members includes knowledge of the Derby Festival, poise, intelligence, personality, academic excellence and campus/community involvement.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ryan |first=Jacob |url=http://www.whas11.com/sports/derby-horse-racing/Kentucky-Derby-Festival-Queen-crowned-203921291.html |title=2013 Kentucky Derby Festival Queen crowned | WHAS11.com Louisville |publisher=Whas11.com |date=2013-04-20 |accessdate=2013-11-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105160318/http://www.whas11.com/sports/derby-horse-racing/Kentucky-Derby-Festival-Queen-crowned-203921291.html |archivedate=2013-11-05 |df= }}</ref>
The court attends nearly 70 events during the two-week period leading up to the Kentucky Derby. The queen is selected by a spin of the wheel at the Annual Fillies Derby Ball.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefillies.org|title=ACW Fillies - Home|website=www.thefillies.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref> The festival saw this method of queen selections as the most fair way to select from their court and the tradition continues today. Each member of the court is awarded a $2000 scholarship, an entire wardrobe for the festival, VIP access to all events and a chauffeur for the entire two weeks of the official Kentucky Derby Festival.
===Thunder Over Louisville=== [[File:Thunder Over Louisville.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Fireworks at Thunder Over Louisville]] The festival's first major event is [[Thunder Over Louisville]]. Thunder kicks off with a day-long air show ranked as fifth-largest in the United States{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} and the largest [[fireworks|fireworks display]] in North America.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lammers|first1=Braden|title=Distinguished service awards presented to the men behind Thunder Over Louisville|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/louisville/news/2014/04/11/distinguished-service-awards-presented-to-the-men.html?page=all|accessdate=October 16, 2014|work=Louisville Business First|publisher=[[American City Business Journals]]|date=April 11, 2014}}</ref> The approximately 30 minute firework display begins at nightfall. Thunder Over Louisville's fireworks have been designed and performed by [[Zambelli Fireworks|Zambelli Fireworks International]] since 1991.
=== Fest-a-Ville === During the festival, much of [[Louisville Waterfront Park|Waterfront Park]] is billed as "Fest-aVille". It hosts a number of events, including the Chow Wagon, rides, and concerts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/krogers-fest-a-ville/|title=Kroger's Fest-a-Ville℠|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/chow-wagon/|title=Chow Wagon®|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>
=== Poster === Each year, an official Derby Festival poster is unveiled and prints are sold to help finance festival events. Artists and photographers who have produced the prized posters include [[Peter Max]] and Michael Schwab.
=== Pegasus parade === The first event held by KDF was the 1956 Pegasus Parade.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/pegasusparade/|title=Republic Bank Pegasus® Parade|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref> The parade is held annually on the Thursday before Derby.<ref name=":0" />
=== Sports === Various sport competitions are held as part of the Festival. From 1973 to 2017, the Festival hosted the Kentucky Derby Festival [[Basketball]] Classic.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.courier-journal.com/story/sports/preps/kentucky/2018/02/01/kentucky-derby-festival-basketball-classic-canceled-2018/1087768001/|title=No hoops for you: Kentucky Derby Festival cancels high school basketball all-star game|work=The Courier-Journal|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en}}</ref> Since 1974, a [[Pro–am|pro-am]] [[golf]] tournament has been held.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/pro-am/|title=Kentucky Derby Festival® Foundation Pro-Am Golf Tournament|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>
==== Races ==== [[File:Great Balloon Race.jpg|thumb|225x225px|The Great Balloon Race]]A number of races take place in the festival. The Kentucky Derby Festival [[Mini marathon|miniMarathon]] and [[Marathon]] occur the Saturday before the Kentucky Derby; USA Track and Field named the miniMarathon among the nation's top 50 races.{{When?|date=April 2018}}{{Cn|date=April 2018}} The mini has been held since 1974.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://derbyfestivalmarathon.com/history/|title=Race History|last=|first=|date=|website=derbyfestivalmarathon.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref> That same Saturday is typically also when the Great [[Hot air ballooning|Balloon Race]] is held,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/u-s-bank-great-balloon-race/|title=U.S. Bank Great BalloonFest: Great Balloon Race®|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref> the culmination of the hot air balloon-themed BalloonFest.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/u-s-bank-great-balloonfest/|title=U.S. Bank Great BalloonFest℠|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>
Recognition is given to Louisville's restaurant employees with the [[Run for the Rosé]], where waiters and waitresses run an [[obstacle course]] while carrying trays of glasses filled with White Zinfandel Wine. Servers finishing with the best time and most wine remaining in the glasses win prizes.
For the annual [[bed]] races, businesses create themed mobile beds that are paraded before being race on an indoor track with costumed employees.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/great-bed-races/|title=Thorntons Great Bed Races|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref> The Great [[Steamboat]] Race usually takes place in the week before Derby, where the [[Belle of Louisville]] typically takes on at least one challenger.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/great-steamboat-race/|title=Great Steamboat Race Presented by IBEW Local 369|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>
=== Miscellenous === Since 1997, a spelling bee has been held for the festival.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.kdf.org/spelling-bee/|title=Ford Motor Company Spelling Bee|last=|first=|date=|website=discover.kdf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>
== Pegasus pins == Since 1973, KDF has sold a plastic [[Lapel pin|pin]] for the Kentucky Derby featuring a [[pegasus]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pegasuspins.com/collector-info/pin-trading-schedule-price-guide/|title=Pin Trading, Schedule & Price Guide|last=|first=|date=|website=pegasuspins.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pegasuspins.com/faqs/|title=Pegasus Pin FAQs|last=|first=|date=|website=pegasuspins.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref> The pin is used as proof of purchase for admission to a number of the KDF events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pegasuspins.com/pegasus-pin-admission-events/|title=Pegasus Pin Admission Events|last=|first=|date=|website=pegasuspins.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>
==Derby cruising== A controversial aspect of the Derby Festival is "Derby Cruising." Though it is not an official or licensed event during Derby Festival, it takes place in the historically black areas of West Broadway on Derby day and the Friday before it. Cruising consists of motorcycles and cars (many elaborately modified) driving slowly down Broadway, pedestrians crowding the sidewalks, and several blocks closed for a festival with rides and street vendors. The gridlock associated with cruising made it difficult for police to respond to instances of violence during 2005 Derby cruising. In 2006, police made an effort to stop cruising, shutting down Broadway except to [[emergency vehicle]]s, which resulted in suggestions of [[racial profiling]] and much public debate about the legitimacy of Broadway cruising as a free alternative to other festivities.<ref name="cj070501">{{cite news|title= City can use plan to stop cruising|date=2007-05-01|author=Adams, Jim|publisher=[[Courier-Journal]]|pages=1A}}</ref>
In 2007, police announced similar plans, although slightly more of Broadway was to remain open, including access to [[Shawnee Park]]. The 2007 plan sparked a lawsuit by business owners and a [[civil rights]] foundation, claiming the shutdown of Broadway during Derby week violated their [[constitutional right]]s and cost them hundreds of thousands of dollars in business. A [[United States federal judge|federal judge]] allowed the plans to proceed, citing concerns about "public safety and the free flow of traffic".<ref name="cj070501" />
In 2008, police again banned cruising, but with a new plan allowing traffic to flow but to have a high number of officers on hand to enforce the city's noise and cruising ordinances, the latter of which prevents vehicles from blocking a roadway.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cruising law stirs debate on fairness, clarity|date=2007-05-27|author=Adams, Jim|publisher=[[Courier-Journal]]|pages=1A}}</ref> Police reported that arrests were down from 2007, although they did shut down a 10-block portion of Broadway for a short time on Derby evening after gridlock developed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cruising arrests down|publisher=[[Courier-Journal]]|author=Hershberg, Ben Zion|pages=5B|date=2008-05-05}}</ref>
