revision.text:
{{Slavery}} '''Trafficking of children''' (aka "Child Labor" and "Child Exploitation) is a form of [[human trafficking]] and is defined as the "recruitment, transportation, transfer, harboring, and/or receipt" of a child for the purpose of slavery, forced labor and exploitation.<ref name="United Nations 2000"/>{{Rp|Article 3 (c)}} This definition is substantially wider than the same document's definition of "trafficking in persons".<ref name="United Nations 2000"/>{{Rp|Article 3 (a)}} Children may also be trafficked for the purpose of [[adoption]].
Though statistics regarding the magnitude of child trafficking are difficult to obtain, the [[International Labour Organization]] estimates that 1.2 million children are trafficked each year.<ref>{{cite web |author=[[ILO|ILO-IPEC]]|title=Child Trafficking - Essentials |url=https://www.ilo.org/ipecinfo/product/download.do?type=document&id=14616 |publisher=ILO |location=Geneva|year=2010|format=PDF}}</ref> In 2012 the (UNODC) United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime reports the percentage of child victims had risen in a 3 year span from 20 per cent to 27 per cent.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arkofhopeforchildren.org/child-trafficking/child-trafficking-statistics|title=What are the statistics on human trafficking of children?|work=Ark of Hope for Children|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-GB}}</ref> Of every three child victims, two are girls and one is a boy. The gender and age profile of victims detected is 17% girls and 10% boys.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arkofhopeforchildren.org|title=Ark of Hope for Children|work=Ark of Hope for Children|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-GB}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=November 2018}} In 2014, research conducted by the anti-human trafficking organization [[Thorn (organization)|Thorn]] reported that Internet sites like Craigslist are often used as tools for conducting business within the industry and that 70 percent of child sex trafficking survivors surveyed were at some point sold online.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/25/sex-trafficking-in-the-us_n_5621481.html|title=70 Percent Of Child Sex Trafficking Victims Are Sold Online: Study|last=Couch|first=Robbie|date=2014-07-25|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-US}}</ref> The trafficking of children has been internationally recognized as a serious crime that exists in every region of the world and which often has human rights implications. Yet, it is only within the past decade that the prevalence and ramifications of this practice have risen to international prominence, due to a dramatic increase in research and public action. A variety of potential solutions have accordingly been suggested and implemented, which can be categorized as four types of action: broad protection, prevention, law enforcement, and victim assistance. {{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}
The main international documents dealing with the trafficking of children are the 1989 [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child]], the 1999 [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention|I.L.O. Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention]] and the 2000 [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children|U.N. Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children]].
== Definition == The first major international instrument dealing with the trafficking of children is part of the 2000 United Nations [[Palermo protocols]], titled the [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children]]. Article 3(a) of this document defines child trafficking as the "recruitment, transportation, transfer, harboring and/or receipt" of a child for the purpose of exploitation.<ref name="United Nations 2000"/> The definition for child trafficking given here applies only to cases of trafficking that are transnational and/or involve organized criminal groups; in spite of this, child trafficking is now typically recognized well outside these parameters.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1">{{cite journal|last1=ILO |last2=UNICEF |last3=UN.GIFT|title=Training Manual to Fight Child Trafficking in Children for Labour, Sexual and Other Forms of Exploitation – Textbook 1: Understanding Child Trafficking|year=2009|url=http://www.unicef.org/protection/Textbook_1.pdf|accessdate=February 9, 2012}}</ref> The [[International Labour Organization]] expands upon this definition by asserting that movement and exploitation are key aspects of child trafficking.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> The definition of "child" used here is that listed in the 1989 [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child]] which states, "a child means every human being below the age of 18 years, unless, under the law applicable to the child, majority is attained earlier."<ref name="United Nations 1989">{{cite journal|last=United Nations |title=Convention on the Rights of the Child |year=1989 |url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/crc.htm |accessdate=March 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611182141/http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/crc.htm |archivedate=June 11, 2010 |df= }}</ref> The distinction outlined in this definition is important, because some countries have chosen to set the "age of majority" lower than 18, thus influencing exactly what legally constitutes child trafficking.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/>
=== Related legal instruments === Many international, regional, and national instruments deal with the trafficking of children. These instruments are used to define what legally constitutes trafficking of children, such that appropriate legal action can be taken against those who engage in and promote this practice. These legal instruments are called by a variety of terms, including conventions, protocols, memorandums, joint actions, recommendations, and declarations. The most significant instruments are listed below:<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/>
==== International human rights instruments ==== These legal instruments were developed by the [[United Nations]] in an effort to protect international human rights and, more specifically, children's rights. * [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights|U.N. Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], 1948<ref>{{cite journal|last=United Nations|title=United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights|year=1948|url=https://www.un.org/en/documents/udhr/|accessdate=April 1, 2012|bibcode= 1952Natur.169T.310.|volume=169|pages=310–311|journal=Nature|doi=10.1038/169310d0|issue=4295}}</ref> * [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child]], 1989<ref name="United Nations 1989"/>
==== Labor and migration treaties ==== The trafficking of children often involves both labor and migration. As such, these international frameworks clarify instances in which these practices are illegal. * [[Minimum Age Convention, 1973|I.L.O. Minimum Age Convention, 1973]]<ref name="min age conv 1973">{{cite journal|last=I.L.O. |title=Minimum Age Convention |year=1973 |url=http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C138 |accessdate=March 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120803220358/http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C138 |archivedate=August 3, 2012 |df= }}</ref> * [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention|I.L.O. Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention]], 1999<ref>{{cite journal|last=I.L.O. |title=Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention |year=1999 |url=http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C182 |accessdate=March 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120802002729/http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C182 |archivedate=August 2, 2012 |df= }}</ref> ** [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Recommendation|I.L.O. Worst Forms of Child Labour Recommendation No. 190]], 1999<ref>{{cite journal|last=I.L.O.|title=Worst Forms of Child Labor Recommendation No. 190|year=1999|url=http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?R190|accessdate=March 10, 2012}}</ref> * I.L.O. Forced Labor Convention, 1930<ref>{{cite journal|last=I.L.O. |title=I.L.O Forced Labor Convention |year=1930 |url=http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C029 |accessdate=March 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20111205032813/http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C029 |archivedate=December 5, 2011 |df= }}</ref> * [[Migration for Employment Convention (Revised), 1949|I.L.O. Migrant Workers Convention (Revised)]], 1949<ref>{{cite journal|last=I.L.O|title=Migrant Workers Convention|year=1949|url=http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C097|accessdate=March 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320105527/http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C097|archivedate=March 20, 2012|df=}}</ref> * [[United Nations Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families]], 1990<ref>{{cite journal|last=United Nations|title=United Nations Convention on the Rights of all Migrant Workers and their Families|year=1990|url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/cmw.htm|accessdate=March 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119100956/http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/cmw.htm|archivedate=November 19, 2011|df=}}</ref>
==== Trafficking-specific instruments ==== * [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children]], 2000<ref name="United Nations 2000">{{cite journal|last=United Nations|title=U.N. Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children|year=2000|url=http://www.unicef.org/protection/convention_20traff_eng.pdf|accessdate=February 9, 2012}}</ref> * The Recommended Principles and Guidelines on Human Rights and Human Trafficking, 2002<ref name="United Nations, Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights 2002">{{cite journal|last=United Nations, Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights|title=Recommended Principles and Guidelines on Human Rights and Human Trafficking|year=2002|url=http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Publications/Traffickingen.pdf|accessdate=March 10, 2012}}</ref> * [[Hague Adoption Convention|Hague Convention on the Protection of Children and Cooperation in regard to Intercountry Adoption]]
==== Regional instruments ==== A variety of regional instruments have also been developed to guide countries in decisions regarding child trafficking. Below are some of the major instruments, though many others exist:<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> * Council of Europe [[Convention on Action against Trafficking in Human Beings]] (Treaty series No. 197), 2005 * Communication to the European Parliament and the Council COM(2005) 514 Final * Multilateral cooperation agreement to combat trafficking in persons, especially women and children, in West and Central Africa, 2006 * Mekong sub regional cooperation agreement to fight human trafficking (COMMIT), 2004
==== National law ==== {{see also|Human trafficking in the United States|Human trafficking in the United Kingdom}} National laws pertaining to child trafficking continue to develop worldwide, based on the international principles that have been established. Anti-trafficking legislation has been lauded as critical by the [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking]], because it ensures that traffickers and trafficking victims are treated accordingly: for example, "if migration laws are used to pursue traffickers, it is often the case that the victims too are prosecuted as illegal migrants, whereas if there is a specific category of 'trafficker' and 'trafficked person,' then it is more likely that the victim will be treated as such."<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> The existence of national laws regarding child trafficking also enables trafficking victims and/or their families to take appropriate civil action.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/>
== Types of child trafficking == The intended or actual after-sale use of the child is not always known.
=== Forced labour === {{see also|Child labour}} The objective of child trafficking is often forced child labour.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Child labour refers specifically to children under a stipulated minimum age, usually 14 at the lowest, being required to work.<ref name="min age conv 1973"/> [[UNICEF]] estimates that, in 2011, 150 million children aged 5–14 in developing countries were involved in child labour.<ref>{{cite journal|last=UNICEF|title=State of the World's Children 2011: Adolescence, an Age of Opportunity|year=2011|url=http://www.unicef.org/sowc2011/pdfs/SOWC-2011-Main-Report_EN_02092011.pdf|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}</ref> Within this number, the [[International Labour Organization]] reports that 60% of child workers work in agriculture.<ref name="I.L.O. 2010">{{cite journal|last=I.L.O.|title=Fast Facts on Child Labour 2010|year=2010|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/@dgreports/@dcomm/documents/publication/wcms_126685.pdf|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}</ref> The ILO also estimates that 115 million children are engaged in hazardous work, such as the sex or drug trade.<ref name="I.L.O. 2010" /> Overall, child labor can take many forms, including domestic servitude, work in agriculture, service, and manufacturing industries. Also, according to several researchers, most children are forced into cheap and controllable labor, and work in homes, farms, factories, restaurants, and much more (Beyrer 16; Gozdziak and MacDonnell 171; Vinkovic 88). Trafficked children may be sexually exploited, used in the armed forces and drug trades, and in child begging.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> In terms of global trends, the ILO estimates that in 2004–2008, there was a 3% reduction in the incidence of child labor; this stands in contrast to a previous ILO report which found that in 2000–2004, there was a 10% reduction in child labor.<ref name="I.L.O. 2010" /> The ILO contends that, globally, child labour is slowly declining, except in sub-Saharan Africa, where the number of child workers has remained relatively constant: 1 in 4 children aged 5–17 work in this region.<ref name="I.L.O. 2010"/> Another major global trend concerns the number of child laborers in the 15-17 age group: in the past five years, a 20% increase in the number of these child workers has been reported.<ref name="I.L.O. 2010" /> A surprised example has occurred in the United States as McCabe (2008) indicates that in the 1990s, huge companies such as Gap and Nike were using industries “sweatshops” that use trafficked children to make their desired products (p. 81).<ref>Mccabe, K. A. (2008). In The Trafficking of Persons. New York, NY: Petter Lang.Mccabe, K. A. (2008). In The Trafficking of Persons. New York, NY: Petter Lang.</ref>
=== Sexual exploitation === {{Main article|Commercial sexual exploitation of children}} {{Sex and the law}} [[Optional Protocol on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography|The Optional Protocol on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography]] is a protocol of the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]], formally adopted by the [[United Nations]] in 2000.<ref name="www2.ohchr.org">{{cite journal|last=United Nations|title=Optional Protocol on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography|year=2000|url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/crc-sale.htm|accessdate=March 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310131154/http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/crc-sale.htm|archivedate=March 10, 2012|df=}}</ref> Essentially, this protocol formally requires states to prohibit the sale of children, child prostitution, and child pornography.<ref name="www2.ohchr.org"/> According to the [[International Labour Organization]], sexual exploitation of children includes all of the following practices and activities:<ref>{{cite web|last=I.L.O.|title=Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children|url=http://www.ilo.org/ipec/areas/CSEC/lang--en/index.htm|accessdate=March 10, 2012}}</ref> * "The use of girls and boys in sexual activities remunerated in cash or in kind (commonly known as child prostitution) in the streets or indoors, in such places as brothels, discotheques, massage parlours, bars, hotels, restaurants, etc." * "The trafficking of girls and boys and adolescents for the sex trade" * "Child sex tourism" * "The production, promotion and distribution of pornography involving children" * "The use of children in sex shows (public or private)" Though measuring the extent of this practice is difficult due to its criminal and covert nature, the [[International Labour Organization]] estimates that there are as many as 1.8 million children sexually trafficked worldwide, while UNICEF's 2006 State of the World's Children Report reports this number to be 2 million.<ref name="I.L.O">{{cite journal|last=I.L.O.|title=Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children and Adolescents: The I.L.O.'s Response|url=http://www.ilo.org/ipec/areas/CSEC/lang--en/index.htm|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=UNICEF|title=The State of the World's Children 2006: Excluded and Invisible|year=2006|url=http://www.unicef.org/sowc06/index.php|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}</ref> The [[International Labour Organization]] has found that girls involved in other forms of child labour - such as domestic service or street vending - are at the highest risk of being pulled into commercial child sex trafficking.<ref name="I.L.O"/> Likewise, Kendall and Funk justifies how “young girls age 12 and under are malleable and more easily trained into their prospective roles as prostitutes, and because virginity is highly prized by certain consumers willing to pay a premium” (31).A variety of sources, including the [[International Labour Organization|I.L.O]], and scholars Erin Kunze and D.M. Hughes, also contend that the increased use and availability of the Internet has served as a major resource for traffickers, ultimately increasing the incidence of child sex trafficking.<ref name="I.L.O"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Kunze|first=Erin I.|title=Sex Trafficking Via the Internet: How International Agreements Address the Problem and Fail to Go Far Enough|journal=Journal of High Technology Law|year=2010|volume=10|series=241-289|url=http://www.jhtl.org/docs/pdf/kunze_formatted_10jhtl241.pdf|accessdate=March 10, 2012}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hughes|first=D.M.|title=The Internet and Sex Industries: Partners in Global Sexual Exploitation|journal=Technology and Society Magazine|year=Spring 2000|volume=19|issue=1|pages=35–42|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?arnumber=828562&tag=1|accessdate=March 12, 2012|doi=10.1109/44.828562}}</ref> In fact, in 2009, Illinois Sheriff Thomas J. Dart sued the owners of [[Craigslist]], a popular online classifieds website, for its "allowance" and "facilitation" of prostitution, particularly in children.<ref>{{cite news|title=Illinois Sheriff Sues Craigslist Over Sex Ads|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=101561684|accessdate=March 12, 2012|newspaper=NPR|date=March 6, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=The Associated Press|title=Illinois: Sheriff Sues Craigslist|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/06/us/06brfs-SHERIFFSUESC_BRF.html|accessdate=March 12, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 5, 2009}}</ref> In response to public and legal pressure, [[Craigslist]] has since blocked all access to its "Adult Services" section.<ref>{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Claire Cain|title=Craigslist Blocks Access to 'Adult Services' Pages|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/05/technology/05craigs.html|accessdate=March 12, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 4, 2010}}</ref>
=== Children in armed forces === {{Main article|Military use of children}} [[Optional Protocol on the Involvement of Children in Armed Conflict|The Optional Protocol on the Involvement of Children in Armed Conflict]] is a protocol of the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]], formally adopted by the [[United Nations]] in 2000.<ref name="http">{{cite journal|last=United Nations|title=Optional Protocol on the Involvement of Children in Armed Conflict|year=2000|url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/crc-conflict.htm|accessdate=March 12, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304201115/http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/crc-conflict.htm|archivedate=March 4, 2012|df=}}</ref> Essentially, the protocol states that while volunteers below the age of 18 can voluntarily join the armed forces, they cannot be conscripted. As the [[Optional Protocol on the Involvement of Children in Armed Conflict|Protocol]] reads, "State parties shall take all feasible measures to ensure that member of their armed forces who have not attained the age of 18 years do not take a direct part in hostilities."<ref name="http"/> Despite this, the [[International Labour Organization]] estimates that "tens of thousands" of girls and boys are currently forcibly enlisted in the armed forces in at least 17 countries around the world.<ref name="ilo.org">{{cite web|last=I.L.O.|title=Child Labour and Armed Conflict|url=http://www.ilo.org/ipec/areas/Armedconflict/lang--en/index.htm|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}</ref> Children conscripted into the armed forces can then be used in three distinct ways:<ref>{{cite journal|last=International Bureau for Children's Rights|title=Children and Armed Conflict: A Guide to International Humanitarian and Human Rights Law|year=2010|url=http://www.ibcr.org/editor/assets/Conflict_Eng.pdf|accessdate=March 11, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110806071249/http://www.ibcr.org/editor/assets/Conflict_Eng.pdf|archivedate=August 6, 2011|df=}}</ref><ref name=Coalition>{{cite journal|last=Coalition to Stop the Use of Child Soldiers|title=Child Soldiers: Global Report 2008|year=2008|url=http://www.childsoldiersglobalreport.org/files/country_pdfs/FINAL_2008_Global_Report.pdf|accessdate=April 12, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307015140/http://www.childsoldiersglobalreport.org/files/country_pdfs/FINAL_2008_Global_Report.pdf|archivedate=March 7, 2013|df=}}</ref> * Direct roles in hostilities (combat roles) * Supporting roles (such as messengers or spies) * For political advantage (such as for propaganda purposes) Recent research conducted by the [[Coalition to Stop the Use of Child Soldiers]] has also noted that girl soldiers must be uniquely recognized, in that they are especially vulnerable to acts of sexual violence.<ref name=Coalition /> The incidence of [[Military use of children|child soldiers]] was the focus of the [[Kony 2012]] movement, that aimed to arrest [[Joseph Kony]], a Ugandan war criminal who is responsible for the trafficking of thousands of child soldiers and sex slaves.<ref name=warrants>International Criminal Court (14 October 2005). ''[http://www.icc-cpi.int/menus/icc/situations%20and%20cases/situations/situation%20icc%200204/related%20cases/icc%200204%200105/press%20releases/warrant%20of%20arrest%20unsealed%20against%20five%20lra%20commanders Warrant of Arrest unsealed against five LRA Commanders] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616142249/http://www.icc-cpi.int/menus/icc/situations%20and%20cases/situations/situation%20icc%200204/related%20cases/icc%200204%200105/press%20releases/warrant%20of%20arrest%20unsealed%20against%20five%20lra%20commanders |date=2011-06-16 }}''. Retrieved 2 June 2009.</ref>
=== Children in drug trades === Children are also used in drug trades in all regions of the world.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Specifically, children are often trafficked into exploitation as either drug couriers or dealers, and then 'paid' in drugs, such that they become addicted and further entrapped.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Due to the illicit nature of drug trafficking, children who are apprehended are often treated as criminals, when in reality they are often the ones in need of legal assistance.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1 /> While comprehensive worldwide statistics regarding the prevalence of this practice are unknown, several useful regional studies have been conducted. For example, the [[International Labour Organization|I.L.O]] has recently investigated the use of Afghan children in the heroin trade and child involvement in the drug trades of Brazil.<ref>{{cite news|last=International Centre on Human Rights and Drug Policy|title=Afghan Children Ensnared in Heroin Trade with Iran|url=http://www.humanrightsanddrugs.org/category/issues/trafficking/|accessdate=March 9, 2012|date=February 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429014857/http://www.humanrightsanddrugs.org/category/issues/trafficking/|archivedate=April 29, 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=I.L.O.|title=Brazil Children in Drug Trafficking: A Rapid Assessment|year=2002|url=http://www.dreamscanbe.org/Reasearch%20Page%20Docs/Souza%20e%20Silva%20and%20Urani%20-%20Brazil%20Children%20in%20Drug%20Trafficki.pdf|accessdate=March 9, 2012}}</ref> Scholar Luke Dowdney specifically studied children in the drug trade in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; he found that children involved in the drug trades are at significantly higher risk of engaging in violence, particularly murder.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dowdney|first=Luke|title=Children of the Drug Trade|year=2003|publisher=Viveiros de Castro Editora Ltda|url=http://www.coav.org.br/publique/media/livroluke_eng.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130205213532/http://www.coav.org.br/publique/media/livroluke_eng.pdf|archivedate=2013-02-05|df=}}</ref>
=== Child begging === Forced child begging is a type of begging in which boys and girls under the age of eighteen are forced to beg through psychological and physical coercion.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009">Delap, Emily. "Begging For Change: Research findings and recommendations on forced child begging in Albania/Greece, India, and Senegal". Anti-Slavery International, 2009. Print.</ref> Begging is defined by the Buffalo Human Rights Law Review as "the activity of asking for money as charity on the street".<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011">Cherneva, Iveta. "Human Trafficking For Begging". Buffalo Human Rights Law Review 17 (2011): 25. LexisNexis Academic: Law Reviews.</ref> There is evidence to suggest that forced begging is one industry that children are trafficked into, with a recent [[UNICEF]] study reporting that 13% of trafficking victims in South Eastern Europe have been trafficked for the purpose of forced begging.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> The United Nations protocol affirms that "the recruitment, transportation, transfer, harboring or receipt of a child for the purpose of exploitation shall be considered 'trafficking in persons' even if this does not involve any of the means set forth in subparagraph (a) of this article."<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> With this definition the transportation of a child to an urban center for the purposes of begging constitutes trafficking regardless of whether this process was enforced by a third party or family member.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/> The severity of this form of trafficking is starting to gain global recognition, with the International Organization for Migration (IOM), [[European Union|the European Union]], the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO), and the [[United Nations]], among others, beginning to emphasize its pertinence.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> The European Union's Brussels Declaration on Preventing and Combating Trafficking includes child begging as one form of trafficking, stating "trafficking in human beings is an abhorrent and worrying phenomenon involving coercive sexual exploitation, labor exploitation in conditions akin to slavery, exploitation in begging and juvenile delinquency as well as domestic servitude."<ref>[http://www.belgium.iom.int/STOPConference/Conference%20Papers/brudeclaration.pdf Brussels Declaration on Preventing and Combating Trafficking] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617051511/http://www.belgium.iom.int/STOPConference/Conference%20Papers/brudeclaration.pdf |date=2012-06-17 }}, 2002,</ref> This issue is especially difficult to regulate given that forced begging is often imposed by family members, with parental power leveraged over a child to ensure that begging is carried out.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/>
==== Demographics ==== By definition child begging occurs in persons younger than eighteen, though forced begging has been found by UNICEF to exist among children as young as the age of two.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/> Incidences of this practice have been recorded by the [[World Bank]] in South and Central Asia, Europe, Latin America, the Caribbean, the Middle East, and West Africa.<ref name="siteresources.worldbank.org">World Bank [http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EXTSOCIALDEVELOPMENT/Resources/244362-1239390842422/6012763-1239905793229/Human_Trafficking.pdf Social Development Notes: Conflict, Crime, and Violence], 2009.</ref>
Most research, such as studies done by UNICEF, suggests that boys are much more likely than girls to be trafficked for the purposes of begging; experts presume this is because there is a greater female presence in trafficking for the purposes of sexual exploitation.<ref name="UNICEF 2006">"Action to Prevent Child Trafficking Report". UNICEF, 2006.</ref> In Albania, where forced begging is a common practice, seventy percent of victims are male.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/>
While concrete figures are difficult to determine, the International Labour Organization (ILO) recently reported that there are at least 600,000 children involved in forced begging.<ref>Craig 2010, p. 29</ref> The problem may be much more extensive, however, with China's Ministry of Civil Affairs reporting that as many as 1.5 million children are forced into begging.<ref name="Pumin, Yin 2011">Pumin, Yin. "Saving Child Panhandlers". Beijing Review 54.9 (2011). 18-19. EBSCOhost. 9 February 2012.</ref> Additionally, a recent study done in Senegal by [[Human Rights Watch]] projected that a minimum of 50,000 children within the country and neighboring nations have been trafficked for the purposes of begging.<ref>Human Rights Watch 2010, p. 10</ref> Begging is often the primary source of income for street children in a number of countries, with a current study conducted by UNICEF finding that 45.7% of children who work on the streets of Zimbabwe engaged in begging, though there is no way of knowing whether it was through forced means.<ref name="unicef.org">UNICEF. "[http://www.unicef.org/evaldatabase/files/ZIM_01-805.pdf Study On Street Children In Zimbabwe]" (2011).</ref>
Gang networks involving forced begging have been found to occur in populations of 500 or greater.<ref name="Burke, Jason 2011">Burke, Jason, and Saad Hammadi. "Bangladesh Arrest Uncovers Evidence of Children Forced to Beg". The Guardian [London] 9 Jan. 2011. Print.</ref>
===Adoption=== Children may be trafficked for the purposes of adoption, particularly international adoption. Children are sourced from orphanages or kidnapped, or parents may be tricked, cajoled or coerced into relinquishing custody. {{Source needed|date=January 2018}} Disreputable international adoption agencies then arrange international adoptions, charging high fees to prospective adoptive parents. The [[Hague Convention on the Protection of Children and Cooperation in regard to Intercountry Adoption]] is an international agreement designed to protect children from such exploitation and to assist in preventing such illegal intercountry adoptions.
==== Causes ====
===== Economic factors ===== Forced begging is a profitable practice in which exploiters are motivated by economic incentives. The business structures of major rings of children trafficked for the purpose of begging have been examined as comparable to a medium-size business enterprise.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> In the most severe cases networks of children forced to beg may generate $30–40,000 USD for the profiteer.<ref>Delap 2009, p. 6.</ref> Though family networks are not nearly as extensive, a study conducted in Albania showed that a family with multiple children begging can earn up to fifteen euros a day, an amount greater than the average national teacher salary.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> Anti-Slavery International asserts that because this income is relatively high many families believe it is the best option available given the lack of existing [[Capability approach|capabilities]]. Capability deprivation, meaning the routine absence of adequate resources that serve in facilitating opportunities, may account for cross-generational begging practices within families.<ref>Delap 2009, p. 12</ref> UNICEF studies have found that begging is especially prevalent among families in which parents are incapacitated in some way, leading children to be the sole providers.<ref name="unicef.org"/>
===== Political factors ===== According to the World Bank forced begging is most commonly found in the Middle East and countries of West Africa, where laws prohibiting begging are scarce and heavy regulation of trafficking absent.<ref name="siteresources.worldbank.org"/> In Zimbabwe, where child begging is especially prominent, the United Nations has indicated many contradictions between the Labour Act of Zimbabwe and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.<ref name="unicef.org"/> Many nations, such as Indonesia, have laws against begging on the books, but the repercussions for such entail temporary detainment and eventual release back onto the streets, which does little to combat the issue.<ref>Sullivan, Kevin. "A Generation's Future Goes Begging". The Washington Post [Jakarta, Indonesia] 7 Sept. 1998. Print.</ref>
===== Cultural factors ===== There are several cultural factors that support begging. In Europe begging is found in a number of minority cultures, especially popular within Roma and nomadic communities.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> In Turkey familial networks of beggars have been documented across three generations, making it deeply ingrained within their survival schemas.<ref name="Craig, Gary 2010">Craig, Gary. "Child Slavery Now". Portland: The Policy Press, 2010.</ref> It is important to note that while these may be culturally rooted practices, juvenile begging by way of familial pressure still falls under the realm of forced begging.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> The transport of children, even one's own, for the purposes of exploitation through begging is a form of trafficking outlined by the United Nations.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/>
Another cultural practice is the resolution of familial debts through the kidnapping and exploitation of one of their children.<ref>Sidner, Sarah. "[http://thecnnfreedomproject.blogs.cnn.com/2011/05/04/gang-profits-from-maimed-child-beggars/ Gang Profits from Maimed Child Beggars]". CNN Freedom Project (2011).</ref>
==== General abuses ==== UNICEF has found that children who are forced to beg by third parties are often removed from their families, surrender the majority of their income to their exploiter, endure unsafe work and living conditions, and are at times maimed to increase profits.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/><ref name="UNICEF 2006"/> The process of [[Mutilation|maiming]], popularized by the film ''[[Slumdog Millionaire]]'', is common given that according to the Buffalo Human Rights Law Review children with apparent special needs often make upwards of three times as much as other children who beg.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> In addition to inflictions such as blindness and loss of limbs, other physical abuses for the purposes of heightening profits include pouring chili pepper on a child's tongue to give the appearance of impeded speech, the use of opium to elicit cries, and administering forced injections of drugs that will increase a child's energy and alertness.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/> Testimonies against trafficking ring gang leaders have discussed the detainment of individuals in small cells devoid of food, water, and light to make victims weak and feeble, and thus more likely to elicit donations.<ref name="Burke, Jason 2011"/>
The conditions in which begging takes place commonly expose children to further physical and verbal abuse, including sexual victimization and police brutality.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/> Research completed by Human Rights Watch revealed that when begging hours are completed for the day children often do not have proper shelter, adequate food, or access to healthcare where they reside.<ref name="Wells 2010">Wells, Matthew. "Off the Backs of the Children: Forced Begging and Other Abuses Against Talibes in Senegal". New York, New York: Human Rights Watch, 2010</ref> Furthermore, many of the gangs which run networks of forced begging have heavy drug involvement, thus the children under their control are often turned into drug addicts in order for them to become further reliant on their exploiters.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/>
==== Long-term implications ==== Studies have shown that children forced into begging primarily receive little to no education, with upwards of sixteen hours a day dedicated to time on the streets.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> With education being a leading method in escaping poverty child beggars have been shown to engage in a cyclical process of continuing this practice cross-generationally.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/> Interviews conducted by UNICEF show that children who beg have little hope for the future and do not believe their circumstances will improve.<ref name="unicef.org"/> Children who work on the streets typically have little or no knowledge of their rights, leaving them especially susceptible to exploitation both as juveniles and later as adults.<ref name="unicef.org"/> Children who beg have also been found by UNICEF to have much higher instances of HIV-infection due to lack of awareness and supervision on the streets.<ref name="unicef.org"/>
==== Solutions ====
===== International action ===== A victim-centered human rights approach to combating trafficking has been internationally renowned as the best possible strategy when addressing this issue, with recourse focusing on punishing the exploiter and rehabilitating the child.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> Some countries who emphasize this method include the United States, with the [[Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000|U.S. Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000]] affirming "victims of severe forms of trafficking should not be inappropriately incarcerated, fined, or otherwise penalized solely for unlawful acts committed as a direct result of being trafficked."<ref name="TVPA 2000">U.S. Trafficking Victims Protection Act 2000, p.1468.</ref>
Other supported methods, such as those outlined by the Buffalo Human Rights Center, include relying on three Ps: protection, prosecution, and prevention.<ref name="Cherneva, Iveta 2011"/> Protection starts with enforcing strict measures on the matters of both trafficking and begging. For many nations the first step is the criminalization of begging and trafficking.<ref name="Craig, Gary 2010"/> Prosecution should be instituted in the form of greater legal ramifications for traffickers, with punishment focused on the exploiter rather than the exploited.<ref name="TVPA 2000"/> This becomes difficult with respect to victims of familial trafficking, considering this would require changes in care placement and strict monitoring of each displaced child's welfare.<ref name="Delap, Emily 2009"/> Many organizations affirm that prevention begins with discouraging donations and improving services so that children, and families as a whole, have greater capabilities.<ref name="Wells 2010"/> Though well-intentioned, by giving child beggars money, individuals only make this practice more profitable, and soon these funds find their way into the hands of the child's abuser.<ref name="Wells 2010"/>
===== Government response ===== In Senegal, where the abuses against [[talibes]] are extensive, there have been several initiatives with the help of [[World Bank|the World Bank]] to put an end this exploitation. First, there is intervention on a community level with education on the validity of some of these Quranic institutions provided to rural villages that typically send their children there. This is supplemented by improved regulation of schools within the nation to ensure that they remain places of education, followed by a greater enforcement of preexisting laws banning trafficking and exploitative begging. Finally, rehabilitation services have been provided with the help of [[Civil Society Organization|CSOs]] to recovered children to provide them with the capabilities they have been denied.<ref name="siteresources.worldbank.org"/>
In Zimbabwe policy has adapted to ensure the safety of all persons under the age of sixteen with the Children's Protection and Adoption Act, however, the government admits that a lack of resources and capital play a critical role in inadequate enforcement.<ref name="unicef.org"/>
In Bangladesh, where there are an estimated 700,000 beggars, a law passed in 2009 banning the practice, though officials report some trouble with enforcement.<ref name="Burke, Jason 2011"/>
In China, the Ministry of Public Security has established a department that solely focuses on child trafficking. Recently the department has instituted a hotline where the public dials 110 to report suspected incidences of forced begging, which law enforcement officials are expected to investigate further. The police are trained to take the children into custody if a blood relationship with their guardian cannot be established, and educate parents on the illegality and dangers of begging if they are those responsible for the child's action. This policy instituted in April 2009 has since led to the recovery of 9,300 children.<ref name="Pumin, Yin 2011"/>
===== NGO initiatives ===== Many NGOs have initiated movements focusing on informing the public on the dangers of donations. As recently reported by UNICEF "certain behaviors, such as giving money to child beggars can also indirectly motivate traffickers and controller to demand children."<ref name="UNICEF 2006"/> The Mirror Foundation's Stop Child Begging Project of Thailand is one such organization that emphasizes eliminating the demand. Their initiatives are focused on educating passersby on the forced begging of trafficked Cambodians within their country to decrease the likelihood of donations.<ref>humantrafficking.org, 2006</ref>
===== Other methods ===== In China, where the kidnapping and forced begging of children has been routinely documented, a multi-media movement has begun.<ref name="Pumin, Yin 2011"/> Here, blogs are utilized to publicize over 3,000 photos of children whose families believe have been abducted for the purpose of begging, with hundreds of thousands of followers who remain on the look out for these children in major urban centers. This campaign has enabled at least six children to be recovered and reunited with their families.<ref name="Pumin, Yin 2011"/>
In instances where begging is religiously sanctioned it has been suggested by [[USAID|USAid]] that religious leaders should outwardly condemn this practice. For talibes religious leaders have been asked to take a stance against begging using passages cited from the Quran, such as "Except paradise, you should not beg anything for the sake of Allah" (8:23), which would help strip the practice of its religious foundation.<ref>"Study on the Practice of Trafficking in Persons in Senegal". USAid (2004). United States Agency For International Development.</ref> In addition, during the time of president Clinton - a former president of the United States-, he took the responsibility of providing protection against child abuse through Internet Service providers (ISP) that can help the law enforcement tracking any suspicious activities including child pornography (McCabe, 2008, p. 247).<ref>McCabe, K.A. (2008). The role of internet providers in cases of child pornography and child protection. Social Science Computer Review, 26(2), 247-251.</ref>
=== Child exchange === In China, in response to adult starvation, some children were exchanged, killed, and eaten. According to Robyn Meredith, "peasants [in the People's Republic of China (possibly in ''ca.'' B.C.770)] turned into skeletons. The nation's farmers, including the residents of Xiaogang, .... [among some] starving families[,] resorted to a practice called ''易子而食'' [meaning "exchanging children to eat"]:... they traded a child for a neighbor's child, then killed and ate the skinny youngster, with the sickening knowledge that their neighbors were devouring their own."<ref>Meredith, Robyn, ''The Elephant and the Dragon: The Rise of India and China and What It Means For All of Us'' (N.Y.: W. W. Norton, 1st ed., hardcover 2007 ({{ISBN|978-0-393-06236-6}})), p. 19 & nn. 10 & 11 (People's Republic of China & ''ca.'' 1958 per p. 18) ("a number of Chinese and Western scholars have documented starvation and cannibalism during Mao's Great Leap Forward, but these accounts of what happened in China's countryside are taken from" Becker, Jasper, ''Hungry Ghosts: Mao's Secret Famine'' (N.Y.: Free Press, 1996), per ''The Elephant and the Dragon'', ''id.'', p. 19 n. 11).</ref>{{Efn|[[Peasant]]s, traditionally farmers who might be slaves, serfs, or free}}{{Efn|[[Xiaogang (disambiguation)]], one of several places in China}}{{Efn|[[Great Leap Forward]], a campaign under Mao Zedong to quickly move China from being agrarian to industrializing and collectivizing to become communist}}
=== Sales motivated by cash === In [[ancient Rome]], according to Keith Bradley, [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] wrote that "there were indigent parents selling their children because they needed the cash."<ref>Bradley, Keith, ''Slavery and Society at Rome'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pbk. 1994 ({{ISBN|0-521-37887-7}})), p. 37 (book on "central period of Roman history", ''ca.'' 200 B.C. to ''ca.'' A.D. 200) (author prof. classics, [[University of Victoria|Univ. of Victoria]]).</ref>
In contemporary Nepal, parents of poor families sell their children to [[orphanage]]s (or sometimes simply hand them over without any payment). The orphanage then misrepresent them as "orphans", ensuring an income for the orphanages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/Unreported-World/episode-guide|title=Unreported World|work=Channel 4}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/dateline/story/transcript/id/601840/n/Nepal-s-Orphan-Trade|title=Nepal's Orphan Trade|work=News}}</ref>
== Mechanisms == In general, child trafficking takes place in three stages: recruitment, movement, and exploitation.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/><ref name="United Nations, Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights 2002"/> Recruitment occurs when a child is approached by a recruiter, or in some cases, directly approaches a recruiter themselves.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Recruitment is initiated in many different ways: adolescents may be under pressure to contribute to their families, children may be kidnapped or abducted into trafficking, or families may be trafficked together.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Then, movement will occur - locally, regionally, and/or internationally - through a variety of transportation types, including by car, train, boat, or foot.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1" /> Ultimately, the final goal of child trafficking is exploitation, whereby traffickers use the services of children to garner illegal profit.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1 /> Exploitation can take place in a variety of forms, including forced labor, sexual exploitation, and child begging, among other practices.
=== Supply and demand framework === Child trafficking is often conceptualized using the economic model of [[supply and demand]].<ref name="United Nations, Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights 2002"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Feingold|first=David A.|title=Human Trafficking|journal=Foreign Policy|year=2005|volume=150|jstor=30048506}}</ref> Specifically, those who are trafficked constitute the "supply", while the traffickers, and all those who profit from the exploitation, provide the "demand".<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Two types of demand are defined: consumer demand and derived demand. Consumer demand is generated by people who actively or passively buy the products or services of trafficked labor.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> An example of this would be a tourist purchasing a T-shirt that has been made by a trafficked child. Derived demand, on the other hand, is generated by people who directly profit from the practice of trafficking, such as pimps or corrupt factory owners.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Scholar Kevin Bales has extensively studied the application of this economic framework to instances of human trafficking; he contends that it is central to an accurate understanding of how trafficking is initiated and sustained.<ref name=Bales>{{cite book|last=Bales|first=Kevin|title=Disposable People: New Slavery in the Global Economy|year=1999|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, CA}}</ref> Bales, along with scholars Elizabeth M. Wheaton, Edward J. Schauer, and Thomas V. Galli, have asserted that national governments should more actively implement policies that reduce both types of demand, thus working towards the elimination of trafficking.<ref name="United States Department of State 2011">{{cite journal|last=United States Department of State|title=Trafficking in Persons Report|year=2011|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/164452.pdf|accessdate=March 10, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Wheaton|first=Elizabeth M.|author2=Edward J. Schauer|author3=Thomas V. Galli|title=Economics of Human Trafficking|journal=International Migration|year=2010|volume=48|issue=4|url=http://nfsacademy.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/02/Wheaton-Economics-of-Human-Trafficking.pdf|accessdate=April 12, 2012|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2435.2009.00592.x|pages=114–41|pmid=20645472}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
=== Social mechanisms === Various international organizations, including the [[International Labour Organization]] and the [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking]] have linked child trafficking to poverty: Living in poverty has been found to increase children's vulnerability to trafficking.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=UNESCO|title=Poverty, Gender, and Human Trafficking in Sub-Saharan Africa: Rethinking Best Practices in Migration Management|year=2005|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001432/143227e.pdf|accessdate=March 10, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Gozdziak 2008">{{cite journal|last=Gozdziak|first=Elzbieta M.|journal=Anthropological Quarterly|year=2008|volume=81|issue=4|title=On Challenges, Dilemmas, and Opportunities in Studying Trafficked Children|jstor=25488246}}{{paywall|via=[[Fondren Library]]}}</ref> However, poverty is only one of many social "risk factors" that can lead to trafficking. As [[UNICEF]] and the [[World Bank]] note, "Often children experience several risk factors at the same time, and one of them may act as a trigger that sets the trafficking event in motion. This is sometimes called 'poverty plus,' a situation in which poverty does not by itself lead to a person being trafficked, but where a 'plus' factor such as illness combines with poverty to increase vulnerability."<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1 /><ref>{{cite journal|last=The World Bank|title=Human Trafficking: A Brief Overview|journal=Social Development Notes: Conflict, Crime, and Violence|date=December 2009|issue=122|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EXTSOCIALDEVELOPMENT/Resources/244362-1239390842422/6012763-1239905793229/Human_Trafficking.pdf|accessdate=April 12, 2012}}</ref> [[UNICEF]], [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking|UN.GIFT]] and several scholars, including Una Murray and Mike Dottridge, also contend that an accurate understanding of child trafficking must incorporate an analysis of gender inequality.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1 /><ref name=Dott>{{cite journal|last=Dottridge|first=Mike|title=Trafficking in Children in West and Central Africa|journal=Gender and Development|year=2002|volume=10|series=1|pages=38–42|jstor=4030680|doi=10.1080/13552070215890}}</ref><ref name=Murray>{{cite book|last=Murray|first=Una|title=Good Practices: Gender Mainstreaming in Actions Against Child Labor|year=2003|publisher=International Labour Organization|location=Geneva}}</ref> Specifically, in many countries, girls are at a higher risk of being trafficked, particularly into sexual exploitation.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1 /><ref name=Dott /> In addition, these international agencies and scholars contend that giving women and men an equal voice in anti-trafficking policy is critical to reducing the incidence of child trafficking.<ref name=Dott /><ref name=Murray />
Studies throughout Europe have identified risks that make children vulnerable to exploitation that are also causes and contributing factors of child trafficking. These include social and economic marginalisation, dysfunctional family backgrounds, experiences of neglect, abuse or violence within the family or in institutions, exploitative relationships, gender-based violence and discrimination, experiences of living or working on the streets, precarious and irregular migration situations, aspirations to work and to earn money and limited opportunities to enter or remain in school, vocational training or regular employment. As the efforts of national governments to improve social safety nets can lessen many of these risks, child trafficking is considered not only a result of criminal activities but also as indicating weaknesses in the national government's ability to effectively safeguard children’s rights to a safe and healthy development.<ref>CARDET, Defence for Children International – Italy et al., IMPACT, Improving Monitoring and Protection Systems Against Child Trafficking and Exploitation, Transnational Analysis, 2013, p. 16.</ref><ref>United Nations Children’s Fund Innocenti Research Centre (2008), [http://www.unicef-irc.org/publications/pdf/iwp_2008_05.%20pdf Young People’s Voices on Child Trafficking: Experiences from South Eastern Europe, Innocenti Working Paper No. IWP-2008-05]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Florence</ref><ref>United Nations Children’s Fund Innocenti Research Centre (2008), Child Trafficking in Europe, A Broad Vision to Put Children First, Innocenti Insight, Florence, pp. 12-16.</ref><ref>Save the Children (2007), Children Speak Out, Trafficking risk and resilience in Southeast Europe, Regional Report, pp. 20-29.</ref>
== Identification == The complex definition of child trafficking and the differences in national laws and interpretations makes the identification of child victims of trafficking challenging. For example, the European debate on child trafficking lacks consensus on how child trafficking is to be distinguished from other contexts of exploitation, from [[social dumping]] of migrants, the sale of children and the smuggling of migrants.<ref>CARDET, Defence for Children International – Italy et al., IMPACT, Improving Monitoring and Protection Systems Against Child Trafficking and Exploitation, Transnational Analysis, 2013, p. 18.</ref><ref>United Nations Children’s Fund Innocenti Research Centre, Child Trafficking in the Nordic Countries, Rethinking strategies and national responses, A Technical Report, 2012, pp. 34-41.</ref>
Once a potential victim has come into contact with state authorities, identifying the child as a victim of trafficking takes time. The process often benefits from a thorough understanding of the child’s story. For a child who is in trouble with the law, hearing the child's full story helps caseworkers and officers determine if the child is actually a victim of a crime herself, such as exploitation, abuse, or trafficking. For a child in an administrative process, such as an asylum procedure, hearing the child's full story helps caseworkers to detect cases of trafficking. Children may be hesitant to share their complete stories with authorities and appointed child welfare professionals. Some service providers have found that establishing trust and a stable relationship with the child encourages increased disclosure of experiences of exploitation and trafficking that might otherwise not be detected. The trust building process can include granting assistance and support services to ensure safety, well-being and development.<ref>Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, Trafficking in Human Beings: Identification of Potential and Presumed Victims, A Community Policing Approach, 2011.</ref><ref>Norway: Coordination Unit for Victims of Trafficking, Guide to Identification of Possible Victims of Trafficking, 2008.</ref><ref>Sweden: Handbook for the identification of child victims of trafficking developed by National Board of Health and Welfare with UNICEF Sweden.</ref><ref>Denmark: Guidelines for identification of victims of trafficking developed by the Danish Centre against Trafficking in Human Beings.</ref>
Identified victims of child trafficking are entitled to special safeguards that all child victims of crimes are entitled to under international law. These safeguards include the right to [[guardianship]], legal assistance and representation, safety and protection, support for physical and psychological recovery and [[social integration|social reintegration]], regularisation of [[Immigration|immigration status]], the right to compensation, and the right to act as a party, or plaintiff, in criminal proceedings. An important safeguard for trafficked children who have been exploited in illegal or criminal activities is the ‘non-punishment clause’. It means that child victims of criminal offences, including human trafficking, are to be protected from sanctions or prosecution for acts that they committed in relation to their situation as victims.<ref>United Nations Children’s Fund, Guidelines on the Protection of Child Victims of Trafficking, UNICEF Technical Notes, 2006.</ref><ref>United Nations Economic and Social Council, Guidelines on Justice in Matters involving Child Victims and Witnesses of Crime, Economic and Social Council Resolution 2005/20, 22 July 2005.</ref>
Articles 19 and 32-36 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child prohibits the exploitation of children in any form and in any context. Any child who is exposed to violence, exploitation or abuse can be considered a victim of crime and enjoys the correlated rights and entitlements, including access to assistance, protection and support, services for recovery and rehabilitation, access to justice, with due procedural safeguards in any related legal or administrative proceedings. Children at risk of exploitation have to be identified and recognised as being at risk. This implies that they have a right to assistance and support in order to prevent their exploitation or any other harm resulting from the risks. Considering the difficulties of identifying children who have been trafficked and the broad protection against all forms and contexts of exploitation afforded under the Convention, a child rights-based approach prioritises the identification of child victims of exploitation or other crime and children at risk. Whether or not exploitation takes place in a context of trafficking is of subordinate relevance for the child rights and protection context. It may interest primarily the law enforcement investigations and the prosecution.<ref>CARDET, Defence for Children International – Italy et al., IMPACT, Improving Monitoring and Protection Systems Against Child Trafficking and Exploitation, Transnational Analysis, 2013, pp. 15-19.</ref><ref>United Nations Children’s Fund Innocenti Research Centre, Child Trafficking in the Nordic Countries, Rethinking strategies and national responses, A Technical Report, 2012, pp. 34-44.</ref>
== Prevalence == It is difficult to obtain reliable estimates concerning the number of children trafficked each year, primarily due to the covert and criminal nature of this practice.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/><ref name="Gozdziak 2008"/> It often takes years to gather and compile estimates regarding child trafficking and, as a result, data can seem both inadequate and outdated.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> This process of gathering data is only complicated by the fact that very few countries publish national estimates of child trafficking.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> As a result, the available statistics are widely thought to underestimate the actual scope of the problem.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/>
=== Worldwide === Trafficking of children has been documented in every region of the world.<ref name="United Nations 2000"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Inter-Agency Coordination Group Against Trafficking in Persons (ICAT)|title=An Analytical Review 10 Years on from the Adoption of the UN Trafficking in Persons Protocol|year=2010|url=http://www.unicef.org/protection/ICAT_Backgound_Paper.pdf|accessdate=February 9, 2012}}</ref> A widely used figure regarding the prevalence of this practice is provided by the [[International Labour Organization]], which estimates that 1.2 million children are trafficked each year; this estimate includes cross-border and internal trafficking.<ref name="I.L.O. 2002">{{cite journal|last=I.L.O.|title=Every Child Counts: New Global Estimates on Child Labour|year=2002|url=http://www.ilo.org/ipecinfo/product/viewProduct.do?productId=742|accessdate=February 18, 2012}}</ref>
=== Regional === Regionally, the [[International Labour Organization]] has provided the following estimates for trafficking of children by region per year:<ref name="I.L.O. 2002"/> * Asia/Pacific: 250,000 children * Latin America & the Caribbean: 550,000 children * Africa: 200,000 children * Transition economies: 200,000 children * Developed/industrialized economies: unknown
As the numbers above indicate, child trafficking occurs the most frequently in Latin America and the Caribbean. Child trafficking is also the most prevalent in developing countries, though it does occur in developed and industrialized economies as well.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1 /><ref name="United States Department of State 2011"/> Notably, the [[United States Department of State]] publishes an annual "Trafficking in Persons" report which provides ample data regarding the prevalence of human and child trafficking in the majority of countries.<ref name="United States Department of State 2011"/> The University of Pennsylvania School of Social Work released a study that estimated as many as 300,000 American youth may be at risk of commercial sexual exploitation at any time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sp2.upenn.edu/~restes/CSEC_Files/Exec_Sum_020220.pdf |title=SP2.upenn.edu |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002000344/http://www.sp2.upenn.edu/~restes/CSEC_Files/Exec_Sum_020220.pdf |archivedate=2008-10-02 |df= }}</ref>
=== History (England)=== According to anthropologist Samuel Pyeatt Menefee, in the late 17th and 18th centuries, in Britain, parents in poverty "sold their children (actually, their children's services, but to all intents and purposes their persons as well)".<ref>Menefee, Samuel Pyeatt, ''Wives for Sale: An Ethnographic Study of British Popular Divorce'' (N.Y.: St. Martin's Press, 1981 ({{ISBN|0-312-88629-2}})), p. 163 and see pp. 163–165 and p. 133 n. 4 for a quotation from ''Jackson's Oxford Journal'' (Oxford, Oxfordshire), Aug. 12, 1797, p. 2.</ref> Sale motivations were more economic than for wife sales<ref name="WivesForSale-p165">Menefee, Samuel Pyeatt, ''Wives for Sale'', ''id.'', p. 165.</ref> and prices, drawing from limited data, "appear to have been fairly high".<ref>Menefee, Samuel Pyeatt, ''Wives for Sale'', ''id.'', p. 165 & n. 20.</ref> Many of the boys sold were climbing boys for chimney sweeps until they were no longer small enough.<ref>Menefee, Samuel Pyeatt, ''Wives for Sale'', ''op. cit.'', p. 163.</ref> Prostitution was another reason for selling a child, usually a girl.One sale was of a niece; another was the sale by a man of the daughter of a woman domestic partner who also ran his business. Some children were stolen and then sold.<ref name="WivesForSale-p164">Menefee, Samuel Pyeatt, ''Wives for Sale'', ''id.'', pp. 164–165 & nn. 19 & 21.</ref>
== Impacts ==
=== Children and families === According to [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking|UN.GIFT]], child trafficking has the most significant impact on trafficked children and their families.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/><ref name=UN.GIFT>{{cite journal|last=UN.GIFT|title=An Introduction to Human Trafficking: Vulnerability, Impact, and Action|journal=United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime|year=2008|url=http://www.unodc.org/documents/human-trafficking/An_Introduction_to_Human_Trafficking_-_Background_Paper.pdf|accessdate=April 12, 2012}}</ref> First, trafficking can result in the death or permanent injury of the trafficked child.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> This can stem from a dangerous "movement" stage of trafficking or from specific aspects of the "exploitation" stage, such as hazardous working conditions. Moreover, trafficked children are often denied access to healthcare, effectively increasing their chances of serious injury and death.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Trafficked children are also often subject to domestic violence; they may be beaten or starved in order to ensure obedience.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> In addition, these children frequently encounter substance abuse; they may be given drugs as "payment" or to ensure that they become addicted and thus dependent on their trafficker(s).<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> As opposed to many other forms of crime, the trauma experienced by children who are trafficked is often prolonged and repeated, leading to severe psychological impacts.<ref name=UN.GIFT /> [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking|UN.GIFT]] reports that trafficked children often suffer from depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder, among other conditions.<ref name=UN.GIFT />
Effects on families are also severe. Some families believe that sending or allowing their children to relocate in order to find work will bring in additional income, while in reality many families will never see their trafficked children again.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> In addition, [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking|UN.GIFT]] has found that certain forms of trafficking, particularly sexual exploitation in girls, bring "shame" to families.<ref name=UN.GIFT /> Thus, in certain cases, children who are able to escape trafficking may return to their families only to find that they are rejected and ostracized.<ref name=UN.GIFT />
=== Communities === Child trafficking has also been shown to have a major effect on communities. If multiple children in a community are trafficked, it can result in the entire community being corrupted, and thus devastated, by trafficking.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Social development efforts are hindered, as trafficked children's educations are cut short.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> As a result of this lack of education, children who escape trafficking may be less able to secure employment later in life.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> In addition, trafficked girls face special obstacles, in that their prospects for marriage might be diminished if the community becomes aware that they have been trafficked, particularly into sexual exploitation.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/>
=== Nations === On a national level, economic development is severely hindered by the lack of education of trafficked children; this results in a major loss of potentially productive future workers.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/><ref name=UN.GIFT /> Children who are able to successfully return to their families often pose a significant financial burden, due to their lack of education, and the illnesses and injuries they may have incurred during trafficking work.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> There are major costs associated with the rehabilitation of these trafficked children, so that they are able to successfully participate in their communities.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk1"/> Furthermore, the persistence of child trafficking indicates the presence of sustained criminal activity and criminal networks, which, in most cases, are also associated with drugs and violence.<ref name=UN.GIFT /> As a result, [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking|UN.GIFT]] has cited child trafficking as a significant indicator of national and global security threats.<ref name=UN.GIFT />
== Proposed solutions == Solutions to child trafficking, or "anti-trafficking actions", can be roughly classified into four categories:<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2">{{cite journal|last1=I.L.O |last2=UNICEF |last3=UN.GIFT|title=Training Manual to Fight Child Trafficking in Children for Labour, Sexual and Other Forms of Exploitation - Textbook 2: Action Against Child Trafficking at Policy and Outreach Levels|year=2009|url=http://www.unicef.org/protection/CP_Trg_Manual_Textbook_2.pdf|accessdate=February 9, 2012}}</ref> * Broad protection: "To prevent children and former victims from being (re)trafficked" * Prevention: "Of the crime of child trafficking and the exploitation that is its end result" * Law enforcement: "In particular within a labour context and relating to labour laws and regulations" * Protection: "all steps towards the redress of their grievance, rehabilitation and helping to establish her/him."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/2065674/Child_Trafficking_Problems_and_Solutions|title=Child Trafficking: Problems and Solutions|author=Bianca Daw|publisher=}}</ref>
Broad protection actions are geared towards children who could potentially be trafficked, and include raising awareness about child trafficking, particularly in vulnerable communities.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2 /> This type of outreach also includes policies geared towards improving the economic statuses of vulnerable families, so that reasonable alternatives are available to them, other than sending their children to work.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2 /> Examples of this include increasing employment opportunities for adults and [[conditional cash transfer]] programs. Another major broad protection program that has been readily endorsed by [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking|UN.GIFT]], the [[International Labour Organization|I.L.O]], and [[UNICEF]] involves facilitating gender equality, specifically by enhancing both boys' and girls' access to affordable, quality education.<ref name=UN.GIFT /><ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2 /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Pinheiro|first=Paulo Sergio|title=World Report on Violence against Children|year=2006| url=https://www.unicef.org/violencestudy/reports/SG_violencestudy_en.pdf |accessdate=February 18, 2012}}</ref> Another way to raise awareness for child trafficking is by communities from all over the world dedicating a week to this situation. Observing the 2012 Human Trafficking Awareness Day in the US, and wider world. Community groups along with police enforcements are collaborating to organize events as well as in depth information sessions and support groups for the victims. The events held by communities could include films, guest speakers, booths, and many more things that can help people understand the seriousness of this issue. The ICE (Human Trafficking) has a help line for victims as well as conducts awareness in the U.S.A communities through the ICE In Plain Sight Campaign.
Preventative actions are more focused on addressing the actual practice of child trafficking, specifically by implementing legal frameworks that are aimed to both deter and prosecute traffickers.<ref name="United Nations, Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights 2002"/><ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2 /> This involves the adoption and implementation of the [[International Labour Organization|International Labour Organization's]] [[international labour standards]], as well as the development of safe and legal migration practices.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2 />
Law enforcement refers to the actual prosecution of traffickers; [[UNICEF]] maintains that successful prosecution of child traffickers is the surest way to send a message that child trafficking will not be tolerated.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2 /> Traffickers can be "caught" at any one of the three steps of trafficking: recruitment, movement, and/or exploitation; anti-trafficking laws as well as [[child labour]] laws must then be appropriately enforced and having them properly implemented. The development of grassroots surveillance systems has also been suggested by [[UNICEF]] which would enable communities to immediately report signs of child trafficking to legal authorities.<ref name=TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2 />Protection begins first with victim identification; child trafficking laws must specifically and appropriately define what constitutes a "trafficking victim".<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2" /> Legal processes must then be in place for removing children from trafficking situations, and returning them either to their families or other appropriate settings.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2" /> Victims should also be provided with individualized and supportive physical and [[Psychological trauma|psychological]] rehabilitation in order to establish him or her self. This recuperation can take quite a length of time but, with the individual having the correct support, they can work towards a functional life.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2" /> Finally, steps should be taken to avoid "double victimization" - in other words, to ensure that formerly trafficked children are treated as victims, and not as criminals.<ref name="TngManualFightTrafficking-Textbk2" /> An example of "double victimization" would be a child who was illegally trafficked into sexual exploitation in the United States, and then, once free from trafficking, is prosecuted for being an illegal migrant. The End Trafficking Project is the initiative to raise awareness about child trafficking and help people take action to protect children. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.unicefusa.org/mission/protect/trafficking|title=Child Trafficking|work=UNICEF USA|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}</ref> The UNICEF has come up with ways to help children from child exploitation and the risk factors that need to be addressed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.unicefusa.org/mission/protect/trafficking|title=Child Trafficking|work=UNICEF USA|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}</ref> These include:
* Helping parents provide a living wage, so the children won't have to support the family * Lobbying governments and others to develop laws and strengthen child protection systems to prevent violence and abuse * Supporting the training of professionals working with children,and police and border officials to help stop trafficking. * Working with communities and organizations to change societal norms that make children more vulnerable to exploitation
=== Relevant organizations === Many organizations have proposed potential solutions to child trafficking. These organizations continue to conduct research concerning this practice and policies that can be implemented to work towards its eradication. The most internationally recognized of these organizations include: * [[United Nations]]<ref>{{cite web|title=United Nations|url=https://www.un.org/en/}}</ref> * [[UNICEF]]<ref>{{cite web|title=UNICEF|url=http://www.unicef.org/}}</ref> * [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] (OHCHR)<ref>{{cite web|title=Office of the High Commissioner of Human Rights|url=http://www.ohchr.org}}</ref> * [[United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking]] (UN.GIFT)<ref>{{cite web|title=United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking|url=http://www.ungift.org}}</ref> * [[International Labour Organization]]<ref>{{cite web|title=International Labour Organization|url=http://www.ilo.org}}</ref> * [[United States Department of State]]<ref>{{cite web|title=United States Department of State|url=http://www.state.gov}}</ref> * [[ECPAT International]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ECPAT International |url=http://www.ecpat.net/EI/index.asp |accessdate=April 1, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130322221502/http://ecpat.net/EI/index.asp |archivedate=March 22, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
== In popular culture == * ''[[A Modest Proposal]]'', by [[Jonathan Swift]], was ironic fiction proposing the selling of children to save Ireland from starvation;<ref>Harmon, William, & C. Hugh Holman, ''A Handbook to Literature'' (Upper Saddle River, N.J.: Prentice Hall, 8th ed. 2000 ({{ISBN|0-13-012731-0}})), p. 278.</ref> the proposal was not intended to be literal. * In China, ''[[The White Haired Girl|The White-Haired Girl]]'', an opera, a film, and a ballet, includes, according to [[Frank Dikötter]], a farmer's daughter being sold by a landlord and creditor, who had seized her from the farmer who was her father, into slavery<ref>Dikötter, Frank, ''[[The Tragedy of Liberation]]: A History of the Chinese Revolution, 1945–57'' (New York: Bloomsbury Press, 1st U.S. ed. 2013 ({{ISBN|978-1-62040-347-1}})), p. 194 & n. 45 (author Dikötter chair prof. humanities, University of Hong Kong & was prof. modern history of China, School of Oriental & African Studies, Univ. of London.</ref> * In [[Avicii]]'s video for the song [[For Better Days]], the mini-story revolves around two exploited children who take vengeance on their exploiters * In [[Guardians of the Galaxy]], [[Yondu]] takes [[Star-Lord]] as a child because his dad asked him to do that, but Yondu raised him instead.
