The '''Violence Initiative''' was a proposal for research into reducing violence in [[United States|American]] [[inner city|inner cities]], first announced on February 11, 1992 at a meeting of the [[National Mental Health Advisory Council]] by psychiatrist [[Frederick K. Goodwin]], then director of the [[Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health Administration]]. It was initially proposed as a large-scale program of research into inner-city violence, with the intent of identifying children and youth believed to be biologically or genetically pre-disposed to violence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19951010-01.2.11&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN------|title='Violence Initiative' part of fatal legacy|last=McCarthy|first=Timothy|date=10 October 1995|work=Columbia Daily Spectator|access-date=2018-01-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> Goodwin further suggested that future research possibilities might include interventions and targeted treatments in order to divert these youth from possible future violence.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/opinions/1992/03/01/science-and-sensitivity/285e7541-3b66-48c4-9cc9-55fb37d013f9/|title=Science and Sensitivity|last=Rensberger|first=Boyce|date=1992-03-01|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-01-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
The proposal drew public controversy after portions of Goodwin's speech which compared inner-city youth to [[primate]]s in the [[jungle]] were leaked publicly.<ref name=Wright95>{{Cite magazine|last=Wright|first=Robert|date=1995-03-13|title=The Biology of Violence|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1995/03/13/the-biology-of-violence|magazine=New Yorker|page=68|doi=|pmid=|access-date=2018-01-10}}</ref> The remarks were initially publicized by [[Peter Breggin]], an outspoken opponent of [[psychiatric medication]] and [[Genetics of aggression|biological explanations of crime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://discovermagazine.com/1994/nov/violencegenesand446|title=Violence, Genes, and Prejudice|last=|first=|date=|work=Discover Magazine|access-date=2018-01-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1992/07/29/science-or-social-control/928d795e-6c3f-4fd7-988a-2a01b1093e78/|title=Science or Social Control?|last=Gilliam|first=Dorothy|date=1992-07-29|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-01-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Goodwin first apologized for the primate remarks in an interview on February 21, calling them "insensitive and careless."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/22/us/federal-official-apologizes-for-remarks-on-inner-cities.html|title=Federal Official Apologizes For Remarks on Inner Cities|last=Hilts|first=Philip J.|date=1992-02-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> He resigned from his position on February 27, 1992.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/28/us/health-official-quits-after-harsh-criticism.html|title=Health Official Quits After Harsh Criticism|date=1992-02-28|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
Further controversy arose when Breggin drew a connection between the Violence Initiative and Goodwin's earlier research into the use of psychiatric drugs as a means of controlling violent behavior, ultimately suggesting that the Violence Initiative would result in widespread use of psychiatric drugs to control the behavior of inner-city minority youth.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/09/18/opinion/l-us-hasn-t-given-up-linking-genes-to-crime-153192.html|title=Opinion: U.S. Hasn't Given Up Linking Genes to Crime|last=Breggin|first=Peter|date=1992-09-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>{{Sfn|Wright|1995|p=69}} Critics denounced the proposal as racist and called for it to be cancelled.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=6pcR4buMC00C&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=%22violence+initiative%22+goodwin&source=bl&ots=oXKiQJGqon&sig=nlY8JR-AmYmELmPiVlAEr8TNAEM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjqjKqtvM3YAhVD54MKHUpIC3o4ChDoAQgmMAA#v=onepage&q=%22violence%20initiative%22%20goodwin&f=false|title=Family Bonds: Genealogies of Race and Gender|last=Feder|first=Ellen K.|date=2007-08-06|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780198042976|location=|pages=78|language=en}}</ref> Supporters of the proposal countered that the proposal had been a legitimate research topic, and had become a victim of "[[political correctness]]."<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Primate comparison == Goodwin's controversial remarks drew a direct comparison between inner-city youth and male monkeys in the wild:
{{cquote|If you look, for example, at male monkeys, especially in the wild, roughly half of them survive to adulthood. The other half die by violence. That is the natural way it is for males, to knock each other off and in fact, there are some interesting evolutionary implications of that because the same hyperaggressive monkeys who kill each other are also hypersexual, so they copulate more to offset the fact that more of them are dying.
Now, one could say that if some of the loss of social structure in this society, and particularly within the high impact inner-city areas, has removed some of the civilizing evolutionary things that we have built up and that may be it isn't just the careless use of the word when people call certain areas of certain cities jungles, that we may have gone back to what might be more natural, without all the social controls that we have imposed upon ourselves as a civilization over thousands of years in our evolution.<ref name=randall>{{cite web|title =Violence as a Public Health Issue|last=Randall|first=Vernellia R.|url = http://academic.udayton.edu/health/05bioethics/slavery04.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-31| publisher = academic.udayton.edu}}</ref>}}
These remarks were described as "rambling" by the ''[[Washington Post]]'' during the initial controversy.<ref name=":0" /> In a 1995 article, the ''[[New Yorker (magazine)|New Yorker]]'' characterized his logic as "obscure" and "not entirely clear"; the same article reported Goodwin stating that he had made the remarks "impromptu - and after a wholly sleepless night".<ref name=Wright95 />
The comparison of inner-city youth to primates, accompanied by the use of the word "jungle", was widely viewed as racist.<ref name="Wright95" /><ref name=":1" /> Writer [[Tom Wolfe]], though sympathetic to Goodwin's argument, stated in his 1996 essay "Sorry, But Your Soul Just Died", that this "may have been the stupidest single word uttered by an American public official in the year 1992".<ref>{{cite web| title = Sorry, But Your Soul Just Died| last = Wolfe| first = Tom| url = http://www.orthodoxytoday.org/articles/WolfeSoulDied.php| publisher = OrthodoxyToday.org| accessdate = 2008-05-31}}</ref>

'''1st Lt. Walter Haut''' (June 3, 1922 – December 15, 2005) was the [[public information officer]] (PIO) at the 509th Bomb Group based in [[Roswell, New Mexico]] during 1947. Early on July 8, 1947 he was ordered by the base commander, [[William H. Blanchard|Colonel William Blanchard]], to draft a [[press release]] to the public, announcing that the [[United States Army Air Forces]] had recovered a crashed "[[flying saucer|flying disc]]" from a nearby ranch. The press release garnered widespread national and even international media attention. The U.S. Army Air Force retracted the claim later the same day, saying instead that a weather balloon had been recovered. Haut also received some criticism and ridicule in the nation's press for putting out the original press release. The series of events eventually became known as the [[Roswell UFO Incident]].
When interviewed about the incident decades later, he claimed only a minor role, but he expressed his belief that there was "no chance" senior officers who handled the recovered material, including base commander Blanchard, mistook a weather balloon for a flying saucer.
He later claimed greater involvement, including seeing alien corpses and a craft at a base hangar and handling the strange crash debris.
== Biography ==
Walter Haut was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] on June 3, 1922. During [[World War II]], he was a [[Bombardier (air force)|bombardier]] flying 35 missions against Japan. At [[Operation Crossroads]], the [[A-bomb]] tests at the [[Bikini atoll]] in the summer of 1946, he dropped instrument packages to record data from the bomb blasts. In 1947, he became the public information officer for the [[509th Atomic Bomb Group]] at [[Roswell Army Air Field]] in [[New Mexico]]. The base commander, [[Colonel]] [[William H. Blanchard]], was a close personal friend.
In 1991, Haut and two other men founded the International UFO Museum where he presided as president until 1996.<ref>Pflock, p.51</ref> Haut died on December 15, 2005 at the age of eighty-three.
==Haut and the Roswell UFO incident==
In the first book on the subject, ''The Roswell Incident'', Haut was said to be "not a witness."(p. 72) He told interviewers in 1979 that base commander Colonel William Blanchard asked him to write and distribute the press release but when Haut asked to see the object in question was told "his request was impossible." (p. 73)
In ''UFO Crash at Roswell'', Haut appears as a witness, though not to any of actual debris. During a March 1989 interview he said he knew "nothing" about what was recovered. (p. 139) He described being asked by Blanchard to write the press release. "I didn't hear about it until, I guess, Jess [Jesse Marcel, head intelligence officer, who initially investigated and recovered some of the debris] was on his way to the flightline." (ibid) He did, however, describe what Marcel told him: "It was something he had never seen and didn't believe it was of this planet. I trusted him on his knowledge." (p. 142) He further stated: "I think there was a giant cover-up on this thing." (p. 143)
An affidavit signed May 14, 1993, he repeated the above claimed sequence of events and added "I believe Col. Blanchard saw the material, because he sounded positive about what the material was. There is no chance he would have mistaken it for a weather balloon. Neither is there any chance that Major Marcel would have been mistaken.<ref>Karl Pflock, ''Roswell: Inconvenient Facts and the Will to Believe'', p.261; [http://www.roswellproof.com/haut.html#anchor_9 copy of 1993 affidavit]</ref>
By this time, Haut, along with Max Littell and [[Glenn Dennis]] had opened the International UFO Museum and Research Center.<ref>Pflock, p.51</ref>
Then, in a recorded interview from 2000 with Wendy Connors<ref>[http://www.nicap.org/bios/connors.htm bio - Wendy Connors<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and Dennis Balthauser,<ref>[http://www.truthseekeratroswell.com Truthseeker at Roswell - Dennis Balthaser Independent Roswell Research, Journalist and Lecturer<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Haut claimed to have personally viewed an extraterrestrial or alien craft and a body in a Roswell Army Air Field base hangar and being present at a senior staff meeting where a [[cover-up]] of events was discussed. Haut also placed [[Brigadier General]] [[Roger M. Ramey]]<ref>[http://roswellproof.homestead.com/Ramey_info.html Ramey_info<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> head of the Eighth Army Air Force in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], at the meeting. Ramey would later tell the press it was in fact a misidentified weather balloon after Haut had put out the press release of the recovered "flying disc."<ref>http://www.nicap.org/bios/connors.htm; [http://www.roswellproof.com/haut_2000_interview.html transcript of interview]</ref>
In December 2002, Haut also signed a sealed affidavit in which he went into more details about the craft, debris, bodies, and cover-up. Both the interview and affidavit were not to be released until after his death.<ref>[http://www.roswellproof.com/haut.html text of affidavit]</ref>
The full text of the affidavit was first published in June 2007 in the book ''Witness to Roswell: Unmasking the 60 Year Cover-Up''.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Witness-Roswell-Unmasking-60-Year-Cover-Up/dp/1564149439 Witness to Roswell]'' by Tom J. Carey and Donald R. Schmitt</ref> According to the authors, Haut had sworn to his friend Colonel Blanchard not to reveal in his lifetime the events he witnessed and therefore told researchers either that he couldn't remember or that he had only prepared and released the information that was given to him at the time and denied he knew anything else.<ref>Carey & Schmitt, 212-213</ref>
In his affidavit, Haut stated that on July 8, 1947, following the press release he put out in the afternoon, he was taken out to a base hangar by Colonel Blanchard. There he saw an egg-shaped craft about 15 feet long and several small bodies about four feet tall with large heads. He was convinced the bodies were alien and had come from a crashed spacecraft.
Haut also stated that there had been two major crash sites that he had become aware of the day before, the first a large [[debris field]] about 75 miles northwest of Roswell (the site investigated by Major Marcel), and the second, about 40 miles north of town, where the main craft and bodies were found. The north site had just been found by civilians on July 7, and apparently word had already gotten out about it in the public.
At the staff morning meeting on July 8, which Haut said he attended, key officers at the base were briefed and strange debris was handed around, which nobody could identify. Haut also said there was a discussion as to what the public was to be told. General Ramey had flown in to attend the meeting. Haut said Ramey suggested telling the public about the more distant debris field as a diversion from the more accessible and important body/craft site. He felt Ramey was following orders from [[The Pentagon]]. Haut added he was not aware at the time exactly what information was to be divulged. But the press release he put out a few hours later spoke of the more distant site in general terms, saying that the Army Air Force had come into possession of a "flying disc" with cooperation of a local rancher, and it was being flown on to "higher headquarters" after being examined at the base. "Higher headquarters" quickly turned out to be Gen. Ramey in Fort Worth, who within a few hours said the "flying disc" was a misidentified weather balloon.

[[MacArthur Genius Grant]] | spouse = [[Paula Foege]] }} '''William Herbert Foege'''{{cite news |author= The Crimson Staff|date=June 5, 1997 |title= Eleven granted honorary degrees|newspaper=[[The Harvard Crimson]] |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=217756}} [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]], [[Master of Public Health|M.P.H.]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|f|eɪ|ɡ|i}};{{cite web | author = Hagen R |title= Say how? A pronunciation guide to names of public figures |url= https://www.loc.gov/nls/about/organization/standards-guidelines/efgh/#f |date=May 8, 2006 | publisher = [[National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped]], [[Library of Congress]] |accessdate=September 26, 2009}} born March 12, 1936) is an American [[epidemiologist]] who is credited with "devising the global strategy that led to the eradication of [[smallpox]] in the late 1970s".{{cite news |author=Paulson T |title= Carter hails UW's shy hero Foege. New building named for health leader is dedicated |url= http://www.seattlepi.com/local/262295_carter09.html |newspaper=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=March 9, 2006 |accessdate=September 26, 2009}} Foege also "played a central role" in efforts that greatly increased [[immunization]] rates in developing countries in the 1980s.{{cite journal |author= Kim JY|title= America's best leaders. William H. Foege, physician. A lifelong battle against disease |url= https://www.usnews.com/articles/news/best-leaders/2007/11/12/william-h-foege.html | journal =[[U.S. News & World Report]] |date= November 12, 2007 |accessdate=September 26, 2009}} In June 2011, he authored ''House on Fire: The Fight to Eradicate Smallpox,'' a book on modern science, medicine, and public health over the smallpox disease.{{cite news |title=President Obama honors William Foege, Emory professor emeritus, with prestigious award |date=May 29, 2012 |work=Woodruff Health Sciences Center |url=http://www.news.emory.edu/stories/2012/05/jj_foege_medal_of_freedom/index.html }} == Early life == Foege was born March 12{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} 1936 in Decorah, Iowa. He was the third of six children born to William A. Foege, a [[Lutheran]] minister, and Anne Erika Foege.{{cite news |title= Families that work – an occasional series: Rev. William A. Foege's family never had much money, and never felt deprived |author= Maynard S |newspaper= The News Tribune (Tacoma, Washington) |date=October 7, 1998}} The family lived in [[Eldorado, Iowa]] in [[Fayette County, Iowa|Fayette County]], starting in 1936 and moved to [[Chewelah, Washington]], in 1945. In his younger days he was inspired by the life of his uncle, a Lutheran missionary to [[New Guinea]]. He became interested in science at age 13 when working at a pharmacy, and read extensively about the world (e.g., [[Albert Schweitzer]]'s work in Africa) while in a [[Orthopedic cast#Body casts|body cast]] for several months at age 15.{{Cite journal | author = Foege WH | title = The wonder that is global health | journal = Nat Med | volume = 7 | issue = 10 | pages = 1095–6 | date = October 2001 | doi = 10.1038/nm1001-1095 | pmid = 11590422 | url = http://www.laskerfoundation.org/awards/pdf/2001_foege.pdf | access-date = October 6, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110616214434/http://www.laskerfoundation.org/awards/pdf/2001_foege.pdf | archive-date = June 16, 2011 | dead-url = yes | df = mdy-all }} When a teenager he expressed a desire to practice medicine in Africa. == Education == Foege received a B.A. from [[Pacific Lutheran University]] in 1957.{{cite web |title=William Foege, Affiliate Professor, Epidemiology |url= http://sph.washington.edu/faculty/fac_bio.asp?url_ID=Foege_William |publisher=[[University of Washington School of Public Health]] |accessdate=September 30, 2009}} He attended medical school at the [[University of Washington]], where he became interested in [[public health]] while working "after school and on Saturdays" at the [[Public Health - Seattle & King County|Seattle–King County Health Department]]. After receiving his M.D. in 1961, he completed an internship with the [[United States Public Health Service]] hospital at [[Staten Island]] in 1961–1962. He participated in the [[Epidemic Intelligence Service]] (EIS) of the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) between 1962 and 1964, assigned to [[Colorado]].{{cite journal |year=1986 |title= William H. Foege, MD, MPH, assumes APHA presidency |journal=Am J Public Health |volume=76 |issue=2 |page=208 |url= http://www.ajph.org/cgi/reprint/76/2/124.pdf|doi=10.2105/AJPH.76.2.124}}{{cite news |title= A global vision to save millions – William Foege wants all world's children immunized by 1990 |newspaper= The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution |date=December 12, 1985 |vauthors=Graham K, Heys S }} When Foege was with the EIS, he was inspired by [[Alexander Langmuir]] to pursue global health, and spent a short time with the [[Peace Corps]] in India under [[Charles Snead Houston]]. Upon reading a lecture on priorities in public health by [[Thomas Huckle Weller]],{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1056/NEJM196309262691306 | author = Weller TH | title = Questions of priority | journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 269 | pages = 673–8 |date=September 1963 | pmid = 14050972 | issue = 13 }} Foege entered the [[Professional degrees of public health|Master of Public Health]] program at the [[Harvard School of Public Health]] where he studied with Weller. He received his M.P.H. in 1965. == Career == Foege's research includes [[child survival]] and [[Child development|development]], [[injury prevention]], population, [[preventive medicine]], and public health leadership—particularly in the developing world. He is a strong proponent of [[disease eradication]] and control and has taken an active role in the eradication of [[Guinea Worm Disease]], polio and measles, and the elimination of [[river blindness]].http://depts.washington.edu/epidem/fac/facBio.shtml?Foege_William He has held various positions during his career: *Director, [[Centers for Disease Control]], 1977–1983 *President, Co-Founder, [[The Task Force for Global Health]], 1984-1999{{Cite web|url=http://www.myajc.com/news/news/local/decatur-nonprofit-has-helped-save-millions-of-chil/nn2Fd/|title=Decatur-based Task Force for Global Healthsaves children's lives|last=Miller|first=Andy|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-14}} *Senior Fellow, [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation#Global Health Program|Global Health Program, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]]{{cite web | url = http://www.gatesfoundation.org/leadership/Pages/william-foege.aspx | title = William Foege, M.D., M.P.H | author = Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation | accessdate =September 26, 2009 }} *Advisory Board Member, [[Emory University]] Global Health Institute{{cite web | url = http://www.sph.emory.edu/GHI/aboutUs/advisoryBoard/foege.php | title = Emory Global Health Institute Advisory Board.
